results.content:
As a complete newbie to programming I find this course extremely relevant and a great starting block for anyone wanting to gain some experience. I started this course because I had some ideas I have always wanted to turn into reality, I never really knew where to start.

This course really does start with the very basics depending on how you view it and progressively gets harder and harder, it gives you great understanding of how things are and would be implemented with regards to web development, yet at the same time allows you to think outside the box and find other solutions, which I believe is a must in order to learn and absorb.

I can say I find this course very addictive and leaves you asking question after question. In the end it leaves you feeling confident and definitely gives you a huge amount of ability, even shortly into the course. It actually left me with so much confidence I was opening up other text editors and trying to work on my own project (without copy and paste) :) sometimes distracting.

Reece is quick to answer questions polite and make things easier for you too see. I enjoy it and I am glad I have the course material to revert to if and when I need, so much I bought it twice lol. 

Thankyou reece :)

response.content:
Hi Adam! I'm so happy you like the course! I love this 'addictive' feeling of finding of finding a great project to work through! I'll always be here if you need me or have any questions! 
Thanks so much for the kind words,
Reece
response.content_html:
Hi Adam! I'm so happy you like the course! I love this 'addictive' feeling of finding of finding a great project to work through! I'll always be here if you need me or have any questions!
Thanks so much for the kind words,
Reece

results.content:
Reece is an experienced developer, however the entire course is one long and very fast paced code-along with few explanations. 

The object oriented part means 2 huge classes that are used through out the project. Also there are a lot of bad practices, not using functions and outputting Javascript from PHP, making the whole code a mess and a nightmare to debug. The file structure had many of the files in the root directory.

So in conclusion, it was an ambitious effort, but the execution was not impressive.

Also Udemy appreciates if the courses are constantly updated. All main current PHP courses are written in version 5.x. Meanwhile PHP reached version 7.2. I am not saying to rewrite entire courses, but mentioning some of the newer features of the language and redoing or adding new features to the course projects would be nice.

results.content:
This was a good resource for PHP and even JavaScript if you dont know it already. My one suggestion is to use a Error Handler class to write your error messages in one location then refer to that class to output the error. That way when doing documentation or even just updating issues you can simply update that class and it will output where necessary vs. writing the error specifically to each case. If you have questions about what I'm talking about I'm happy to answer. I'm a software engineer who wanted to know more about PHP so I purchased this course. We use it for our documentation engineer and it helps a great deal. Thanks for your videos, they were excellent!!!

One last thing... What if I want to filter chat based on what is said? I can do this with adding some C# or Angular to the site, but is there a direct way in PHP to filter what is added to the feed?

My only critique is that I'd wish it was more Boostrap focused (rather than manually creating a lot of the CSS classes).

The material of this course seems quite good. (I'm about 1/3 of the way through, I believe.) But according to my calculations, the transitions before and after each (usually fairly short) section, over the spread of the entire course, will add 45 minutes to the time it takes to finish the course.

You'll learn a little about the languages used, and connecting to/manipulating MySQL. And that's great for me, because I already have some familiarity with the languages, and mostly wanted to see "how he built it." 

But, man! An additional 45 minutes just for unnecessary transitions? This course would easily get another star from me if it weren't for that.

results.content:
To a relatively new beginner at web developing(learned for 6 months front-end & back-end using php, but took a 1.5 year break and practically forgot everything), this course is easy to understand and follow, while also being practical in future applications. Other courses that i have taken in the past for beginners up to intermediate levels were hard to understand for me and I didn't understand the WHY of the php codes. I mainly had issues in the past on understanding how to write the back-end portion of the website using php, but this guy explained it really well for me. Every time he writes a php code snippet, he explains what it means in layman's term.

But it might have been easier and quicker for me to understand the php codes now, since I have taken other web developing courses in the past along with programming courses at university.

None the less, this guy gets to the point and is a good instructor on this site.

results.content:
Puh... what to say... well if you finish this course you sure will have build a social media website with PHP and MySQL...

Apart from the instructor talking and typing very fast without a lot of breaks, the course is easy enough to follow and to complete.

But! For being an experienced Developer, Reece makes a lot of questionable design choices. I only finished the Registration/Login-Form so far but the ? in my head are popping up constantly.

It begins with basic things like setting the name entries between 2 and 25 characters - a simple Google search would show you that "E" is a very common korean Surname - and unfortunately E can never sign up to our website! If aspiring developers learn their routines through courses like these it is no wonder that PHP has a bad reputation.

Another thing is the exlusion of special characters for the password. Like any security expert or password manager will recommend "!"§$%()&/" to include in the passwords while our app only allows A-Za-z0-9 and with this our password table is basically exposed to any simple dictionary-bruteforce-attack.

And furthermore the instructor encrypts the passwords with MD5 - and just a look at the passwords in the database makes it clear that this is really not good security anymore... A weak password like "123456" will always turn up as the same MD5-Hash - thats basically like not having any encryption at all... a Google search then shows that MD5 is actually not recommended by PHP anymore - and those recommendations are years old!

So overall the course is a mixed bag. On the one hand you will learn and do a lot of PHP but it is often outdated or has a bad design.

results.content:
Too be honest, I'm giving up on the course just over a 1/4 of the way in.  Before I get to the why's which I think are important, I will say I think the project is really nice and definitely one of the reasons that attracted me to this course. Seeing it through to completion would be pretty cool and it looks pretty slick, so if you want to make a 'facebook copy' for your own use, then its probably worth taking the course - IF you are ok with the below;

1) Reece talks really fast a lot of the time and often trips up on some words, which makes the course hard to follow sometimes

2) Start/End of video have loud transitions with music for some reason. Its awful and annoying trying to skip it. Was a bad choice to have this.

3) Now the real meat. I am here primarily to learn more about PHP OOP and Bootstrap, which the course seemed to be based on, but neither are properly used...

4) Bootstrap gets installed, then Reece uses a lot of his own CSS to do things Bootstrap can do natively which was infuriating

5) Most of the PHP is basic procedural PHP, then Reece just randomly starts adding classes, with little explanation as to what OOP is, why he is doing things in any detail and just said "OOP is easy, you will pick it up". No explanations about the MVC.

6) I've got nearly 20 years commercial experience in procedural PHP and a lot of the ways Reece was coding had me cringing a bit and its really not anything like the best way to do things for a lot of what was done.

I'm REALLY sorry Reece, quite a lot of criticism there which I hate to do, but just being honest about my experience.

As I say, if you want to make a really nice looking FB clone to use for a project, then I really applaud Reece as this has a lot of great functionality. But if you already know PHP well or wanted to increase your knowledge of OOP and advanced techniques, then you will probably get frustrated quickly.

results.content:
Definitely NOT a BEGINNER course. It uses OOP PHP, so if you not familiar with Object-Oriented Programming and/or PHP, you might want to learn it BEFORE or ALONG with this course. Especially since the instructor does not explain much of it.

This is course is a follow along with the project kind of course. It doesn’t really cover much of the PHP code or what it does. Even though the project is exiting, you are not going to learn much just by copying code from the screen. Keep in mind, that the instructor also types and speaks VERY FAST, which definitely contributes to the level of frustration. 

If you are looking for a project to add to your portfolio, it is also important to mention that it’s a bit outdated and its code structure is not very well organized. (HTML, PHP, and JavaScript are all piled up on top of each other.) So your best bet might be to start learning PHP/OOP PHP with MVC and AJAX on your own first, and then follow the course and rebuild the project from the ground up.

With that in mind, it is still a pretty cool course. And I like the project a lot. I just wish I knew that it won’t cover a lot of PHP you will be using to build it. And I wish that instructor spent more time explaining how the code works, or at least pointed students to the resources that do.

However, the instructor and the teaching assistant are on point at answering students' questions, which is very nice! Overall, not a bad course, but might be quite frustrating for a beginner.

results.content:
First, I want to direct your attention to the last paragraph of the description of the course, which says:

"Some of the techniques and methods used are not the most efficient way to do things [...], but in my opinion, they are the easiest to teach in a short amount of time and easiest to pick up having never used the skills before."

What this doesn't tell you, however, is that the site is not only not build with best practices in terms of efficiency, but it seriously lacks in regards to security as well.
Now, I understand it is a good idea to simplify things to convey concepts. But that should always happen in conjunction with a pointer to the actual solution or it should at least be mentioned that things are not handled like that in the real world.

I only noticed this because I have some prior coding experience,  but it would still take me a lot of guesswork to figure out which parts are applicable to proper projects and which are not.

This is not suited to be used as a "REAL Social Network", as the title  wants to suggest.
You'll learn basic PHP syntax and some frontend stuff, too, but if you want to take it any further than just impressing your friends with a "real" social network, this is not for you. Because there is no way to tell which parts of it are usable in real projects and which are not, other than just learning the whole thing elsewhere.

I'll rate the course 2,5/5 anyway, simply because the instructor is very responsive to all questions asked and seems to be a very friendly guy all around.
And if all you want is just a dummy social media page built on basic PHP, go ahead. It's nothing more than a prototype, though.
Personally, I'll request a refund.

results.content: Great course.  I'm about 1/4 of the way through.  Unlike many other large project based courses here on Udemy that either utilize old out of date frameworks or copy paste huge chunks of code sans explanation this one is clear, concise, focused and easy to follow along.  If you are 100% new to web programming and don't already know the basics of markup, loops, logic, etc. this is not where you want to start.  However, if you have some degree of experience programming and want to see a social networking project taken from start to finish this is the one.  A few caveats, however.  Don't expect consistent production quality code.  (too much overhead for a course of this nature ) and if you plan to host this project online realize you are in for a lot of work refactoring for security, of which only the basics are considered herein.  The lack of security and occasional sketchy codeblock are the reasons I took off a star.  Nevertheless, I still recommend the course wholeheartedly. results.content:
I think Reece did a good job in teaching this course. Things are explained quite well, and he is very friendly and responsive when you ask questions. Occasionally, there are some bugs in the code, and the steps and methods the instructor used in debugging is informative as well.

I didn't give 5 stars because of some issues. Sometimes when an error occurs, it was not mentioned until the next lesson. So be sure to check the next lesson as well when there's an error.

Also, on some rare occasion, the instructor had to go off-screen to fix a persistent error, and then return on the next lesson explaining what went wrong with the previous lesson's code. When this happened, sometimes the instructor also fixed some minor typo in the code. The problem is, this minor fix is not shown in the video, and sometimes the code won't run because of it.

results.content:
Not five stars because of some false advertising and lack of promised responsiveness with questions. He also does not fully explain many things, or says that he will cover it later to only gloss over it slightly, so he is kind of spacey.

He advertises the course to be for beginners, although it clearly is not. You need to have the basics of php, html/css, and javascript/general object oriented programing to have any idea of what is going on. 

On the plus side if  you just have the basics of those covered, he will walk through and explain how to piece a social media website. It was not a waste of time for me, and therefore worth 3.5 stars. That being said, while I did follow along and write everything out, as long as you keep up with what he is saying, that is really good enough.

results.content: This is an absolutely amazing course, highly recommended! I decided to take this course after graduating from a 12-week full stack developer bootcamp. We covered so much stuff in that bootcamp that I was really lacking some understanding when it came to backend and mysql. I now feel as though I have a much firmer grasp on those concepts and could not be happier with the outcome of this course. The idea of working on one big project is what I think makes this course work so well, and it helped me understand that even the most complicated applications are usually many simpler functions and programs pieced together to make something greater than the sum of its parts. Reece is a great instructor, upbeat, knowledgable, and he would always answer any questions I had in a very timely fashion (within 6 hours every time). Cannot recommend enough 10/10!

results.content:
It's an awesome feeling to be taught by Ewen McGregor...not sure why he is pretending to be someone else by the name of Reece...but ok I will humour him.  Joking asides, Ewen...I mean Reece delivers a fluid narrative implementation of an advance website project...A Facebook clone.  

I'll be honest, I have not completed everything because I have been picking and choosing the modules that I need for my own side project that I am working on in tandem.  

This is not a schooling course that teaches the basic theory of everything to do with web development.  It's a "build one big as project with me" course in which you are guaranteed to learn a LOT along the way as Reece explains everything he implements.  

The point of this course for me is that you learn fast and get results fast in learning new concepts, structure and advance techniques to achieving an immediate substantial goal with impressive results.

Of course, doing a fast-paced course like this means, not everything you learn will stick.  You have to keep building more projects for it all to stick.  But I also recommend using W3Schools as a companion reference. You can also do what I do, work on a different project with similar coding crossovers.

You are not going to get quizzes or practical exercises here...that is not the aim of this course.  Again, this is a "BUILD a...." course. You want traditional schooling, go for a "Learn blah blah..." or "become a full-stack blah blah..." or "the complete blah blah...."  course...if you want that journey.  Yes, they are in-depth and teaches almost everything at beginners to intermediate level...but do we want to devote months to learning everything?  How about learning what you need to to achieve your desired immediate aim in a much shorter time frame with a sense of accomplishing something huge?  That's what I went for and that's what this course delivers.

For me, it's satisfying to build a complex project even if not everything I learn sticks but I know it will when I keep going with new projects and Reece has made plenty more courses like this to make that knowledge "stick" whilst accomplishing huge projects such as a Spotify and Youtube clones.
  

There are some things I would have wanted...I would have like to have seen a design strategy plan for the project before implementation.  Perhaps a flow chart, So we can get an idea of how one plans and builds such a project before getting down and dirty into coding.  

But I give this course fullest rating for one MOST IMPORTANT factor.  I value a Udemy course above all else if there is an active Q&A with either the instructor or a teaching assistant. And guess what, Reece himself answers every single Q&A (as far as I have observed) almost to an unhealthy level!  I mean there are some questions I think he doesn't even need to bother answering but he does and with a sense of enthusiasm and passion.  He answers questions with a full understanding and often outside the scope of the course.  

The Q&A is a big deal to me on Udemy courses.  And I am not fond of any course that does not take advantage of it, nor do I appreciate courses that sway you to go outside Udemy to some discord channel at the sacrifice of Udemy Q&A.   Q&A is where its at and Reece...well, that is where he is at!  And he's got other newer courses on here, I expect he's on those Q&As too. The time he gives to students is more valuable than even the course itself.  

Thank you, Mr MrGregor, you have vastly improved my web development skills in a short period of time.  

I also look forward to your course on trainspotting...

results.content:
Some of the coding examples use poor practice. E.g Hitting the database numerous times - just to generate a 'username' (consider the situation if the one millionth 'John Smith' registered with your server application).  

I think it is fine to show examples which may be considered 'poor practice' - but you should flag this - perhaps - with an example later on - on how to improve it.
(eg. Having the username being a concatanation of firstname, surname and the primary key 'id' - would remove the need for the SQL server bashing 'While loop' in your register.php script)

Some of your data validation could be done at the client end - with javascript. I appreciate there may be times when you may want to (or have to) validate on the server - but you commentary/text should mention the reasons and pitfalls of server/client validation.


On the positive side - your commentary gets straight to the point.

Thank you.

results.content:
I am currently at the 20% point in the course. Let me state at the outset that I give this course content five stars in all important aspects. If you want to create a MySQL-based site without using a canned and therefore restricted interface, this is the course.

Firstly, this course does EXACTLY what it says. If you follow along and write your own code section-by-section, you will create a real social network.  You will use PHP, CSS, HTML, javascript, and store everything in a MySQL database. If you have any programming ability and some general coding experience, you should be able to determine how to easily customize the site for your own uses.

Reece, the instructor, answers course questions almost immediately in the public forum. I've referenced the questions, but have not yet had to post any. He even goes so far as to help people debug their code, which is not technically required by him, as his code is provided at points in the course, up to the time of its presentation in the materials, therefore, he could just say, "Use the code I have provided" instead of taking the time to look through error-filled code.

I have two very minor complaints. He uses UK terminology (since he's from the UK, this is understandable), but in programming this can be confusing. In the US, we call the rounded group indicators "parentheses." In the UK, they are called "brackets." We call the square-sided group indicators "brackets or square brackets." This is critical to get correct in programming. Arrays require the [square ones]; parameter lists require the (rounded ones); functions require {braces}. It can cause confusion. My connection sometimes blurs the video, so the proper {brace}, [bracket], or (parenthesis) is not necessarily shown clearly.  As stated, this complaint is very minor.

My second complaint is that Reece sometimes takes a wrong turn, as it were, in his programming, which we have to go back to correct later.  Proper preparation would have avoided this duplicated corrective effort. Even going back and adding a written video annotation at the point the error is made would help. This has happened maybe three times through 30+ videos, so it is not horribly hard to continue and make the minor corrections when they occur, but it is a time-waster.

I suggest you open a text editor and follow along as Reece does the code, pausing often to type in the code yourself.  Some knowledge of programming is required at the onset, but even without any programming experience, you are going to learn something. 

The course content is five star.  Reece's lack of preparation and sometimes confusing presentation loses one-half to one star, which is why I have rated this course as I have.

I also recommend you find and become familiar with the PHP manual on php.net, stackoverflow.com, w3schools.com, and similar sites for your reference. I suggest, as well, that you debug your own code rather than asking for help.  Most coding is really debugging, and not writing code, until you become fluent with that programming language (when you still spend a lot of time debugging). Do what Reece suggests, when he suggests it. This is not a course for passively watching, but for following along and doing.

Even though I have not given the course five stars, I whole-heartedly suggest anyone interested in developing a functioning MySQL-based site without resorting to canned packages take this course.
